ratings.question_text: What percentage of the reading and other assignments did you complete?

narratives.question_text: How well was the course organized?
comments: I think two plays per class is a wonderful idea.

I thought that the plays on the syllabus were fantastic. I might have switched out Ion and Alcestis for Herakles and Women of Trachis, but both options are great. I think the syllabus has just the right amount of Old Comedy on it. I find the Old Comedy very hard to get through in translation, much more so than the tragedies, and I think the way they Old Comedies are paired with the Euripides are very illuminating.
Excellent course for an introduction into Ancient Greek tragedies (with a dabbling of comedies) with a great eye toward production dramaturgy

narratives.question_text: How effective was the balance between instruction and discussion?
comments: Andy handles discussion masterfully, letting students do much (even most) of the talking and jumping in at key moments to further observations or strengthen them with relevant historical/cultural information.
The call on a student to respond method should be used more often in classrooms.

narratives.question_text: How well did the assigned papers, reports or other projects reflect the aims of the course?
comments: The papers helped us expand on some of the topics that we dealt with during the sessions

The style and rhetorical occasion of the one-to-two-page papers we wrote throughout the semester could have been more clearly articulated. Originally, we were encouraged to "think out loud" about plays for a few pages, but this seems to me less formal than the papers were really supposed to be. More successful papers seemed to make a clear, persuasive argument. The final project, while conceived with the utmost consideration of the professional work dramaturgs will later do, needs sharpening. The expectations for and aims of the assignment were not well-defined, which is evident given the extreme variety of work that was submitted. Were they production notes? Were they ideas for a modern-day adaptation of the play? Should they include potential doubling charts for a play? Should the assignment be written with a specific theater or director in mind? Should we imagine we are directing the production ourselves? It was very difficult to submit satisfactory work.

The project at the end of the year, to create production notes for a possible contemporary production, was a great end to the year, and I gained a lot of insight into the play that I chose to work on (The Bacchae) by doing it.
The biweekly responses kept us focused in our reading and helped our class discussions considerably.

narratives.question_text: How did the amount of assigned reading work with weekly discussion?
comments: 2 plays a week works very well.
The supplementary readings were fascinating but could have perhaps been more deeply integrated in class discussion.

narratives.question_text: The course filled a significant gap in your knowledge of the field.
comments: This course was invaluable in terms of my education as a dramaturg and theater expert.
This class is excellent, and I think near essential for dramaturgs.

narratives.question_text: Regardless of whether or not the course is required, would you recommend it to other students in and outside the department?
comments: Yes, definitely recommended.
Definitely.
Without any reservations. It is an exceptionally good course on the Greeks.
I would absolutely recommend this course. It was such a pleasure!
Yes, definitely.
I highly recommend this course to anyone with the faintest interest in the subject matter. The plays and the instructor are both spectacular.
No doubt

narratives.question_text: The course goals were clearly presented.
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: The instructor has a strong grasp of the course subject matter.
comments: Ridiculously strong.
Andy is a genius. We are so lucky to have him as a professor.
Undeniable

narratives.question_text: The instructor presented the subject matter effectively.
comments: Andy Szegedy-Maszak is an outstanding teacher. He is virtuosically fluent in the material in this class, able to answer any and all questions on the spot and to elaborate on any concepts that students might not know about. He is also good at drawing out the most interesting and provocative and challenging conversation about the texts from the students in the class, making them engaged, active learners and co-leaders n their own educational experience. I cannot overstate how important this class was to me and to my education in theater. It was also a joy.
There were a couple of sessions in which I wanted more close reading and less historical background, but those were few and far between.
Andy has great charisma and a deep understanding of the subject matter and how best to impart it.

narratives.question_text: The instructor was willing to consider diverse points of view.
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: The instructor was willing to answer pertinent questions.
comments: Always very approachable

Andy never shied away from questions, and often provided clear, brilliant answers. Students also had the opportunity to offer their answers to a classmate's question, which made all of us - students and teacher - seem like equals.

narratives.question_text: The grading criteria was clearly explained.
comments: The breakdown of grading was clearly indicated on the syllabus, but the criteria of written assignments could have been clearer.

narratives.question_text: The instructor was available for consultation, discussion and advice.
comments: Always

Above and beyond the call of duty. He answered questions we had about our work in other classes or other projects. He helped me enormously with finding sources for my case study, for example. He is an incredibly thoughtful and generous teacher and mentor.

narratives.question_text: I would recommend this instructor to other students.
comments: YES, YES, YES!!

narratives.question_text: How many of the 14 class meetings did you attend?  Comments:
comments: 13, I didn't go to the first class
All.
All of them.
All 14 of them.
All but one (due to pressing obligations from department assignment due on a class day)

narratives.question_text: Please offer additional comments you have on such topics as: what worked best about the course, what improvements you would suggest, etc.
comments: This class is amazing, and I appreciate that the instructor makes every attempt to have everyone contribute to the discussion.

All the papers, particularly the final, and the class discussions all blended a historical understanding of the plays in their appropriate context, characterological and structural analyses, and production dramaturgy questions. A lot of exposure to new plays, too.
